Ian Badcoe wrote:

>>>      Similarly, the only relationship between different iPhenomes is that
>>>the fitness function has to understand them, but since the fitness
>>>functions are custom anyway (needing to be written afresh for each
>>>problem) that doesn't necessarily translate into any degree of
>>>relatedness at all, with the exception of needing a common anonymous
>>>pointer type for the algorithm to hand over to the fitness function.
>>>
>>>
>>>      
>>>
>>But if we take the black box approach as described above then we have
>>our IPhenome that all fitness functions can understand. Admittedly it's
>>a huge step backwards in terms of the level of abstraction. Anyway lets
>>keep the idea going...
>>    
>>
>
>Hi,
>
>Just a thought that you can always have two levels of abstraction 
>here, a totally generic outer layer, where the Phenome is not assumed 
>to take or return anything or exhibit any particular property except 
>to be evaluatable by some Fitness class, and an inner level, which 
>all you current stuff would fit in, where you have refined the 
>interfaces that the Fitness and Phenome classes will use, but not yet 
>what they use them for...
>  
>
Good idea. I've read through the C# generics docs now which includes a 
few usage scenarios, a comparison with C++ templates and a few words 
about possible pitfalls. All I can do now is have a go and see what I 
come up with. I have used C++ templates before but only for trivial 
container class scenarios, and that was 5 years ago, but since then I 
have missed not having templates available at times.

Colin.
